conversation.text: This is a recipe on how to make bibingka, a popular cake in the Philippines served during special occasions.
evidence: Bibingka is a popular cake served during special occasions in the Philippines.

conversation.text: Ok, what do I do first?
First start by preparing a baking pan (13-inch by 9-inch) with butter, shortening or nonstick cooking spray.
evidence: Prepare a 13-inch by 9-inch (33-cm by 23-cm) baking pan by greasing it with butter, shortening, or nonstick cooking spray.

conversation.text: I don't have a baking pan. What else can I use?
What do you have that can be used for baking?
I have a 24-inch baking tin
You can use the baking tin. We will adjust the amount of ingredients accordingly
Thank you. What's next?
Next, combine half of the cream cheese with 1 cup (100ml) of sugar
evidence: Combine the two ingredients in a large bowl and beat them together with an electric mixer on low speed for roughly 30 seconds, or until thoroughly creamed together.

conversation.text: How do I combine them together?
You should beat them together with an electric mixer on low speed for roughly 30 seconds
evidence: beat them together with an electric mixer on low speed for roughly 30 seconds, or until thoroughly creamed together.

conversation.text: I do not have an electric mixer. What can I do?
You can use a ladle or whisk to blend the ingredients until they are thoroughly creamed together
What is next? I have done this
Before moving on, have you scraped the sides of the bowl so that all the cream cheese and sugar have been blended in?
evidence: Scrape the sides of the bowl to ensure that all the cream cheese and sugar have been blended in.

conversation.text: Yes. Done. What is next?
Add half the eggs into the mixture and stir it in to blend them in
evidence: Add the eggs to the cream cheese mixture

conversation.text: How to stir the eggs?

You should be stirring well enough to blend the egg in. Once you have blended in the eggs, you must add half of the baking powder, sweet rice flour, melted butter, vanilla, cream of coconut, milk and crushed pineapple to the mixture
evidence: stirring well enough to blend the egg in after each additio

conversation.text: Do I add them all at the same time?
No, you should add them one at a time, and continue to stir the mixture until it is smooth. When you add the flour, you should mix 1/2 cup (125ml) at a time to minimize risk of lumps forming
evidence: Add them one at a time, stirring after each addition

conversation.text: What is next after this?
Have you mixed everything and is it smooth?
evidence: our the batter into your prepared pan.

conversation.text: Yes it seems smooth now
Now pour the batter into the baking tin you prepared earlier, and then sprinkle the top with half of the brown sugar and 1 tbsp (15ml) of granulated sugar
evidence: Pour the batter into your prepared pan.

conversation.text: I am getting bumps. What do I do?
You should break up lumps with a fork or spatula. Have you checked for any air bubbles?
evidence: Break up any lumps with a fork or spatula

conversation.text: Yes there are air bubbles. What should I do?
You can remove any air bubbles by gently tapping the baking tin against the counter
evidence: Remove any air bubbles by gently tapping the bottom of the pan against the counter.

conversation.text: Okay, what's next now?
You can put the baking tin with the batter in the over to bake for 1 hour.
How high do I set the oven?
The oven should be preheated to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (180 degrees Celsius).
How do I know when it is cooked?
The bibingka is done when the edges turn slightly crispy and the center is baked through. You can check the center by inserting a toothpick. If it comes out clean it is ready.
evidence: The cake is done when the edges turn slightly crispy and the center is baked through

conversation.text: It is cooked now. Anything else?
You should let the cake cool to room temperature in the tin.
evidence: Let the cake cool to room temperature in its pan.

conversation.text: How do I serve it?
Do you want to serve it now or later?
evidence: Serve while still somewhat warm, or place the squares in an airtight container and serve later

conversation.text: I want to keep it for later
If you plan to serve later, after the cake cools you can cut it into even squares and place them in an airtight container. Do you plan on eating it in the next 1 to 2 days or in 1 to 2 weeks?
evidence: place the squares in an airtight container and serve later

conversation.text: I want to keep them for a few weeks
To preserve the freshness, you can put the container in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.
evidence: o preserve the freshness of the cake for 1 to 2 weeks, place it in the refrigerator.

conversation.text: Thanks. Its all done now

recipe.title: How to Make a Gourmet Bibingka

procedure.summary: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (180 degrees Celsius).
procedure.description: Bibingka is a popular cake served during special occasions in the Philippines. Prepare a 13-inch by 9-inch (33-cm by 23-cm) baking pan by greasing it with butter, shortening, or nonstick cooking spray. Note that this version of the recipe does not require the use of banana leaves.

procedure.summary: Cream together the cream cheese and 2 cups (500 ml) sugar.
procedure.description: Combine the two ingredients in a large bowl and beat them together with an electric mixer on low speed for roughly 30 seconds, or until thoroughly creamed together. Scrape the sides of the bowl to ensure that all the cream cheese and sugar have been blended in.
Add the eggs to the cream cheese mixture, stirring well enough to blend the egg in after each addition.

Add the baking powder, sweet rice flour, melted butter, vanilla, cream of coconut, milk, and crushed pineapple to the batter. Add them one at a time, stirring after each addition. When done, continue stirring until the batter is smooth. When adding the flour, you should mix it into the batter 1/2 cup (125 ml) at a time and stir after each addition. Doing so minimizes the risk of lumps forming in your batter.

procedure.summary: Pour the batter into your prepared pan.
procedure.description: Once the batter is in the pan, sprinkle the top evenly with the brown sugar and an additional 2 Tbsp (30 ml) granulated sugar. Check the batter for lumps or air bubbles. Break up any lumps with a fork or spatula. Remove any air bubbles by gently tapping the bottom of the pan against the counter.

The cake is done when the edges turn slightly crispy and the center is baked through. Check the center by inserting a toothpick into the cake. If it comes out clean, the cake is ready. Let the cake cool to room temperature in its pan.

After the cake cools to room temperature, cut it into 12 to 24 even squares and remove those squares from the pan. Serve while still somewhat warm, or place the squares in an airtight container and serve later. If you plan on eating the cake in the next 1 to 2 days, you can store it at room temperature. To preserve the freshness of the cake for 1 to 2 weeks, place it in the refrigerator.
